Params[3]: It is the afternoon of the following day when Bella enters Base South-3.
Noan is looking down at the manga in his hands, reading silently. The only thing different from before is that he is using a pear blossom as the bookmark.
I thought you were taking a walk. You went to pick flowers?
...Kind of.
Hard to find a pear tree these days.
Any news?
Yeah.
She sits across Noan with a solemn expression.
She died... three years ago. She got ill. Didn't even live to see the rebellion.
She left this journal before she died and gave her possessions to a friend.
Bella waves the thin booklet in her hand.

She kept believing that... things would get better after the rebellion won. There would be schools on the lower level; people wouldn't have to fight for food or the bathroom. Then she would be brave enough to find me.
What do you think? Has her dream come true... or has everything gone to shit?
She struggles to hold back her tears.
Don't you cry. Tears are useless. They can't save anyone.
...Don't repeat what my mom would say. And aren't you the one crying?
He is sobbing too.
So what if I repeat her words? That just proves that it's a universal truth passed down from generation to generation.
Just because it's passed down from our elders doesn't mean it's true. A lot of their ideas are outdated.
It's still better than those fantasies you won't stop reading. Ordinary folks will never become the all-powerful heroes in your Cardman Rider books.
Cardman Riders aren't all-power. Their stories are captivating only because they struggle too.
They both look up and frown, their grief suppressed again.
The real world isn't like your story. We don't always stand back up after we fall.
So you do realize that? I thought you were all "adversity builds character," like your books.
Adversity is always destructive. I'm just willing to believe that it can make me a better person.
That's just wishful thinking you use to make yourself feel better.
Nothing wrong with making yourself feel better. People aren't supposed to stay stuck.
You smiled so freely when I first met you, but look at your face now. Stuck, see?
Surely someone who never smiles doesn't get to say that about me.
Bella sneers.
What happened on the train that day that made you this way?
Haven't you been listening to what people were saying?
Those were their stories, not yours. Shrek isn't your real name, is it?
Does it matter?
Obviously. A name represents a person's past and present.
Some past is just trouble. I don't want to explain and justify myself wherever I go.
If that still bothers you, then you haven't made peace with your past.
I couldn't bring them back even if I made peace. Haven't you also hidden many things from me?
You never asked.
Will you answer if I ask now?
No.
Me neither.
Doesn't it bother you when partners don't communicate with each other?
What's wrong with the way we were? We could talk about our books.
Would that have gotten anything through your thick skull? You have to learn to move past your regrets.
The same goes for you, I reckon.
I need time.
Sure, but so do I.
As their conversation comes to an impasse, Bella changes the subject, her brows furrowed.
Will you go back to Asslam?
And do what?
Fair. As long as Ashlar and his people are there, there's no way you can return... Do you want to keep going with me, then?
Where will you go?
I'm planning to stay here for a while before deciding where to go next. There can't be anything worse out there, after all.
Can I offer you a new, blessed name in this trying time?
That won't be necessary.
I've seen the worst life has to offer. This is as bad as it gets; things can only go up from here.
Who could have known how bad things could get?
It didn't take a disaster, just some other Scavengers like us that we didn't watch out for. Then you were gone.
Thank you, Bella.
I should have said that sooner.
You found me when I was most lost, and you helped me along the way...
You could be quite annoying sometimes—but I suppose there's blame to share. Had I not met you, I won't be standing here, safe and sound.
So, thank you... and I'm sorry... I never told you my story.
Spring will return... Your favorite flowers will bloom again... Only when you told me that did I realize...
...I never got to tell you how I got the pear blossoms in my books.
We were always hiding our past, so we could only talk about the books we loved.
You might have become a merchant for the Forsaken like I did if you had survived. Who knows? Maybe eventually we could be honest with each other... and become real friends.
...It's too late for any of that, isn't it?
Mom, Captain Rachel, Field, Shauna, Niino, Weyland, Ed, Aunt Hill... Everyone I cared for on the train is gone...
...Will you go back to Asslam?
The phantom keeps repeating Bella's words at random. The young man is not bothered and instead starts chatting with the familiar voice.
There's no reason to return anymore.
I ran into Mike at a Forsaken base a few months ago. He told me Niino had passed too.
He said...
Niino's old injuries had long-lasting complications in the first place. He was eating less and less in the last few years, and last month he fell asleep one night and never woke up.
He knew that you survived, and he heard I was preparing to leave Akdilek, so he asked me to give you back your things.
He said no one on the train was going to keep an eye on your things after he was gone.
Mike took out a familiar backpack filled with things Noan left behind.
The short sword Noan used, the weapon designs Rachel gave him, Field's journal, and a manga with a bookmark resting between the pages.
I was going to bring you a piece of candy, but I lost it on my way here. Sigh.
Candy?
You gave my niece your candy on your eleventh birthday, didn't you?
That was so long ago...
I asked him about Asslam, and that was when I found out Ashlar was gone for good.
A lot of things are getting better there. Perhaps a school will show up on the lower level in a few years like your mother wished.
He said our sacrifices weren't in vain...
He turns around, patting the border collie by his side, deep in thought.
So he decided to leave Akdilek and started a new journey.
So have I... After you were gone, I started to teach myself how to perform surgery. There are still a lot I don't understand...
But whatever I can do, I want to give it my all. I want to stay with other people and contribute like I did.
Eventually, I had an arrangement with the Forsaken and became one of their merchants.
But the Red Tide flooded the cities again after the disaster at the Pulia Forest Park Ruins... And it took so many lives.
He stared at the projected phantom in the Red Tide and pauses.
They never stopped fighting, no matter how hopeless it was, even if it cost their lives. The way they fought reminded me of the people on the train.
I was still confused about what came out of my choices and our rebellion after I left Asslam.
What is the point of it when none of you are here anymore, even if our dream has come true?
Only when I saw those who would die defending the people from this calamity did I realize... I was right not to give Ashlar the terminal that day.
I would have betrayed them if I had compromised. Their sacrifices would have been in vain.
Spring will come like you said...
...Winter does not take, for some would light fires with their souls.
Noan looks up and chuckles wryly.
Someone dies defending against this disaster every second... They build a dam with their lives to keep the flood out.
I would have made the same choices I did if I was in the same situation, wouldn't I?
Not because I've decided to give up the possibility they gave me... I'm just making the same choice they did. I'm passing this ticket to the future to someone else.
Goodbye, Bella. I have to take Matches to the Forsaken base. They're still waiting for these serums.
I'm glad I got to hear your voice again, but I hope this is the last time I run into the Red Tide.
Yes. I remember it now.
Conservation area 045, Gray Raven, and the unconscious commandant... I've met them before...
I did make the same choice when I returned to the train with the Forsaken.
The young Construct didn't recognize me, but Jamilah did...
I don't regret anything...
—I've received many gifts from many people in my life. Therefore, I'm willing to sacrifice everything I have in exchange for other people's futures.
—I am loved, and I love them.
—Our deaths and decays are not meaningless. They are the cinders that light up the night.
—They may only be as bright as fireflies, but small and frail as their flames may be, they are enough to light a fuse. All possibilities stem from a big bang, after all.
Noan slowly opens his eyes, having found his answer during his slumber.
Despite the scars all over his body and the constraint that makes him hard to move, all his memories are back, and he is no longer lost.
